dt: {bc}to declare or make legally invalid or void

dt.t: His title to the estate was {it}annulled{/it}.

pt: {sc}nullify{/sc} {sc}negate{/sc} {sc}annul{/sc} {sc}abrogate{/sc} {sc}invalidate{/sc} mean to deprive of effective or continued existence. {sc}nullify{/sc} implies counteracting completely the force, effectiveness, or value of something.
{sc}negate{/sc} implies the destruction or canceling out of each of two things by the other.
{sc}annul{/sc} suggests making ineffective or nonexistent often by legal or official action.
{sc}abrogate{/sc} is like {sc}annul{/sc} but more definitely implies a legal or official act.
{sc}invalidate{/sc} implies making something powerless or unacceptable by declaration of its logical or moral or legal unsoundness.

et: Middle English {it}annullen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}annuller{/it}, from Late Latin {it}annullare{/it}, from Latin {it}ad-{/it} + {it}nullus{/it} not any {ma}{mat|null|}{/ma}
shortdef: to declare or make legally invalid or void
to make ineffective or inoperative : neutralize
